sub_topic: Finding the antiderivative of a function
message_1: Find the antiderivative of the function f(x) = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 4x - 7.
message_2:
To find the antiderivative of the function f(x) = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 4x - 7, we will integrate the function with respect to x. 

The antiderivative F(x) is given by:

F(x) = ∫(2x^3 - 5x^2 + 4x - 7) dx

We will integrate each term separately:

F(x) = ∫(2x^3) dx - ∫(5x^2) dx + ∫(4x) dx - ∫(7) dx

Now, we apply the power rule for integration, which states that the integral of x^n is (x^(n+1))/(n+1) for any real number n ≠ -1:

F(x) = (2x^(3+1))/(3+1) - (5x^(2+1))/(2+1) + (4x^(1+1))/(1+1) - 7x^(0+1)

Simplify the expression:

F(x) = (2x^4)/4 - (5x^3)/3 + (4x^2)/2 - 7x

F(x) = (1/2)x^4 - (5/3)x^3 + 2x^2 - 7x + C

Here, C is the constant of integration. So, the antiderivative of the function f(x) = 2x^3 - 5x^2 + 4x - 7 is:

F(x) = (1/2)x^4 - (5/3)x^3 + 2x^2 - 7x + C
